utterance: Bethany McGregor: of the caribou in Northern Canada, they found that insect populations actually drive these caribou migrations. You know, insect pressure can drive animals to move quite a bit. And then you're not just talking about the insects because then you also have to consider all of the factors that go into where those insects are at and why they're at the populations that they're at that are driving those movements. So you get many layers deep in the complexity of what's driving movement patterns in these different groups and I I feel like it's going to be very challenging to do a broad generalization on that.

annotations.provide supporting evidence: The speaker is providing an example of a study about caribou migrations to support the idea that insect populations drive animal movements.
annotations.expand on existing idea: The speaker expands on the initial idea of insect-driven caribou migrations by adding the complexity of factors influencing insect populations, thus adding layers to the complexity of movement patterns.
annotations.present new idea: The speaker presents the idea that it will be very challenging to do a broad generalization on what drives movement patterns in different groups.

utterance: Daniel Becker: Yeah, I think about um probably migration as kind of as the main movement thing that I I work on but you know, thinking of that as a very specialized form of a general movement process that's just seasonal regular movement and you know, kind of at simplest that can just be governed by, you know, like when you when you depart your wintering grounds, when you depart your breeding grounds and the the distance it takes to connect those two areas is kind of one generalizable framework you can think of and then sort of you know the the parameterization of the timing and and distance kind of governs like the the base you know movement cycle that then we can layer any kind of disease process on top of. Um so I think there's some some big generality there that you can then sort of you know add whatever complexity you need to. Um but it's kind of a nice a nice starting point I guess.

annotations.expand on existing idea: Daniel builds on Bethany's discussion of movement patterns by framing migration as a specialized form of general movement, adding details about seasonal regularity and connecting wintering and breeding grounds.

annotations.present new idea: Daniel introduces a framework for understanding migration based on departure times, distances, and the ability to layer disease processes on top, which is a novel approach not explicitly mentioned before.

utterance: Guillaume Bastille-Rousseau: I I agree with uh with what you just said Daniel about that. I think from a modeling perspective there's a lot of generalization I think we can do. But even with migration, I will say that uh I mean it's very what's driving the actual migration or the factor that are determining the timing of that migration is could be very system and even like within ungulate species will be fairly can be fairly different. So uh yes, I think this I I still struggle to see like if we want to move toward generalize I think the only way we can move towards more generalizable models like for movement is to we need to move away from like specific kind of environmental co areas and more moving towards like more like first principles like well every animal move well most of them move in response to foraging but what is foraging for them is very different depending on the system you deal like what system you're dealing with. So it's somehow we still need to we can make them general generalizable but we still need to have that system specific insights before being able to get at that to an extent.

annotations.express agreement: Guillaume explicitly agrees with Daniel's previous statement about migration as a specialized form of general movement process.

annotations.expand on existing idea: Guillaume builds on the discussion about migration and generalization by adding that the factors driving migration can be system-specific, even within ungulate species.

annotations.present new idea: Guillaume introduces the idea of moving away from specific environmental areas and towards first principles like foraging to create more generalizable models for movement.

utterance: Mark Wilber: I also wonder when thinking about sort of the dimensions of movement that we care about for disease. It seems like we can generalize movement to some degree potentially. Um but then there's particular aspects of movement patterns that are more relevant to disease than others. So you know, thinking about contact being the most the most obvious, but it also could be like time spent in a foraging patch that gains some sort of uh nutrient level that change susceptibility. So there's these different dimensions of movement too um that might be more important when we think about how do they influence disease and kind of wondering if those aspects are also generalizable rather than maybe other movement motifs that may might not be as important for um transmission or something along those lines.

annotations.expand on existing idea: Mark builds on the previous discussion about generalizing movement patterns by considering which dimensions of movement are most relevant to disease, adding the idea of contact and time spent in foraging patches as important factors.
annotations.present new idea: Mark introduces the idea that certain aspects of movement patterns, like contact and time spent in foraging patches, are more relevant to disease transmission than others, suggesting a new way to generalize movement in the context of disease.

utterance: Lauren Charles: Can you just I that was a great thought and I was trying to get it down and I kind of missed. So what what are the dimensions? Can you give me some examples?

annotations.acknowledge contribution: Lauren acknowledges Mark's thought as great, showing recognition of his input.
annotations.ask clarifying question: Lauren asks Mark to provide examples of the dimensions of movement he mentioned, indicating a need for clarification.

utterance: Mark Wilber: Yeah, I guess I was thinking of like so when you think about movement, I guess one of the reasons I'm really interested in movement is because of contact. You know, what does that mean for contact patterns between individuals when we think about movement. Um and so if you think about your like your simplest situation where you have individuals are sort of moving randomly in some area, we have a very predictable contact pattern that emerges from that. Um but we sort of we sort of realize that in some cases that's not how animals are actually moving. And so what what do those what do those contact patterns actually look like and how do they link back to movement? I guess that's kind of what I was saying.

annotations.expand on existing idea: Mark is expanding on his previous idea about dimensions of movement relevant to disease, specifically focusing on contact patterns between individuals.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: Mark explains that he is interested in movement because of contact patterns, defining how movement relates to contact between individuals.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: Mark provides an example of how random movement leads to predictable contact patterns, supporting his point about the link between movement and contact.

utterance: Kezia Manlove: Yeah, and I think that's a place where, you know, like contact in particular, I think fundamentally diverges in some sense from what Guillaume was saying about, you know, depending on how resources defined, I suppose, but as as movement is being fundamentally responsive to resources, which is true if you're thinking maybe about densities, but maybe not true if you're thinking about direct interaction, which is perhaps more um more dependent upon social forces or, you know, yeah, interspecific interactions. So I wonder if it's possible that um that, you know, just just the the mechanisms that underpin specific kinds of interactions that are say or specific kinds of kinds of movement that are salient to disease should be it might be useful to focus more on those as opposed to like movement writ large, you know, because I'm not sure if we need all of movement to understand the salient portions for disease. We might. But I but I don't know.

annotations.expand on existing idea: Kezia builds on Mark's discussion of contact patterns and their relation to movement, adding that contact diverges from Guillaume's resource-based view of movement, suggesting social forces and interspecific interactions are also important.

annotations.present new idea: Kezia introduces the idea of focusing on specific kinds of interactions or movement salient to disease, rather than movement writ large, to understand disease dynamics.

annotations.provide supporting evidence: Avery provides an example of brucelosis and aborted calf to support the idea of interaction being important in modeling disease spread, building on the discussion about movement and disease.
annotations.expand on existing idea: Avery expands on the idea of interaction by providing an example of brucelosis and aborted calf, highlighting how it relates to the location and contact between domestic and wild animals, which builds on the previous discussion about contact patterns and movement.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: Avery explains the concept of interaction in the context of modeling disease spread by giving the example of brucelosis and aborted calf, clarifying that it's not necessarily direct transmission but related to location and contact.

utterance: Liliana Salvador: I was just going to say that uh while I think that um we can generalize um movement properties across systems, I think that that is um and this is like trying to understand how they move, not thinking about why they move. Um but thinking about how movement will implicate disease transmission, I think that that is much more complicated because it will depend so much on the pathogen in cause.

annotations.expand on existing idea: Liliana builds on the discussion about generalizing movement, distinguishing between generalizing 'how' animals move versus 'why,' and focusing on the implications of movement for disease transmission, which she believes is more complex.
annotations.present new idea: Liliana introduces the idea that generalizing movement properties across systems is possible when focusing on 'how' animals move, but understanding how movement implicates disease transmission is more complicated due to pathogen-specific factors.

utterance: Andrew Feig: So if you were thinking about how you would change the way movement is measured, obviously radio frequency tagging has been done for decades, right? annotations.present new idea: The speaker introduces a novel concept by asking how to improve movement measurement techniques to better understand disease transmission, which hasn't been explicitly discussed before.
annotations.ask clarifying question: The speaker is asking how to improve movement measurement techniques to better understand which movements are relevant for disease transmission or risk of disease transmission.

utterance: Kezia Manlove: I guess I think that our information gap is not the biggest information gap, the most critical information gap with respect to movement is not our ability to sense environmental covariance. It is our ability to wall wall color everybody or alternatively to be able to predict contact in some other way.

annotations.present new idea: Kezia introduces the idea that the biggest information gap is not sensing environmental covariance, but rather the ability to track individuals or predict contact, which is a novel concept in the context of the discussion about generalizing movement patterns for disease transmission.
annotations.reject idea: Kezia rejects the idea that the biggest information gap is our ability to sense environmental covariance, without necessarily offering a direct alternative or improvement to that specific approach.

utterance: Lauren Charles: Right.

utterance: Kezia Manlove: And that's really where you're going to get the zootic crossover.

utterance: Bethany McGregor: Right. And just thinking about things that bring the animals together. I know one thing that has come up quite a bit in talking about climate change is the increase um incidence of drought. And when you have drought conditions and you have isolated water um sources, you tend to have more animals congregating around the same water source.

annotations.expand on existing idea: Bethany is expanding on the previous discussion about movement and disease transmission by introducing the idea of animals congregating due to drought, which relates to contact patterns and disease spread.

utterance: Andrew Feig: So how do we merge the data streams? So you know, Mike hasn't introduced himself, he's now back. Uh you know, he's a satellite surveillance kind of person. annotations.present new idea: The speaker introduces the idea of merging environmental change data streams with population movements and potentially incorporating the internet of things and other sensors, which is a novel concept in the context of the discussion.

utterance: Kezia Manlove: I'm going to pause it that that's the wrong data set.

utterance: Kezia Manlove: I guess I think that our information gap is not the biggest information gap, the most critical information gap with respect to movement is not our ability to sense environmental covariance. It is our ability to wall wall color everybody or alternatively to be able to predict contact in some other way. And then also we need a better handle on what's going on within the host, right? We take these hosts, we don't, you know, like when I work on megafauna, right? So we catch an animal, we get one cross-sectional sample, we can we are not calibrated to forecast disease dynamics well or or internal state well within the animal. And so we don't know how susceptibility is varying. So I think that in my mind at least, the information gap surrounding where everyone else is and what's actually happening in the animal seem like way bigger um obstacles than improved remote sensing. However, maybe there's a way to remotely sense moving animals without instrumenting them. That would be awesome.

annotations.reject idea: Kezia rejects the idea that the biggest information gap is our ability to sense environmental covariance, building on Andrew's suggestion to merge environmental data streams with population movements.
annotations.present new idea: Kezia presents a new idea of remotely sensing moving animals without instrumenting them.
annotations.expand on existing idea: Kezia expands on the idea of needing a better handle on what's going on within the host by explaining that current methods of taking cross-sectional samples are insufficient for forecasting disease dynamics.

utterance: Daniel Becker: Yeah, yeah.

annotations.express agreement: Daniel agrees with Kezia's point about the critical information gap regarding movement and disease, as she discussed the limitations of current data and the need for better understanding of contact patterns and host internal states.

utterance: Daniel Becker (University of Oklahoma): Again, sorry, sorry, harp on migration a bit, but the point about radar detection I think is a really exciting area for at least getting a sense of um when animals leave or when they arrive, right? We can pick that up now on our radar systems. And so that's I think a really promising area for making larger scale forecasts than we could based on the idea of, you know, let's put lightweight tags on every single bird or bat or something that we can.

annotations.expand on existing idea: Daniel is building on the previous discussion about movement and disease transmission by suggesting radar detection as a promising area for sensing when animals leave or arrive, which relates to migration patterns discussed earlier.

utterance: Bethany McGregor USDA ARS: Yeah, I wish there was a way, uh, so, so like I said when I introduced myself, I do a lot of blood meal analysis where, you know, I take a blood fed insect and I can tell you what it fed on. And I wish there was a way that we could track individual animals based on the blood meals in these mosquitoes because I think, I know like in the Everglades, they've done this where they've detected the presence of certain critters that they're looking for because they're looking at these blood meals and it helps them to monitor the populations that are present. So, I mean, I think there is a possibility with using blood engorged insects to do some degree of monitoring, but I don't know how useful that is for small scale movement.

annotations.present new idea: Bethany introduces the idea of tracking individual animals by analyzing blood meals in mosquitoes, which hasn't been discussed before in this conversation.

annotations.provide supporting evidence: Bethany supports her idea by mentioning that in the Everglades, blood meal analysis has been used to detect the presence of certain critters, providing evidence for the potential of this method.

utterance: Gonzalo Vazquez-Prokopec: Yeah, there there are ways of sorry, ways of marking organisms, you know, I have some colleagues have done stable isotopes where you feed them, you know, with a diet and then you can test it, but they're really difficult to implement in in rural areas and again working in cities, you know, where we do make sense, but I agree that, you know, it's it's complicated. Um, and I was part at some point of a group called Rapid, you know, research and policy in infectious disease dynamics and we talked a lot about movement. And we came up with, you know, a big limitation which is we don't even have open access data to really mine and and come up with these general patterns that might be there that could help you understand um some of the phenomena on on scalability, different animals or even humans, you know, which is what we were working on. Um, so I agree with this the big challenge is how can you translate from individual studies and and and settings to a trend of mobility, exposure and and I guess emergence. Um, and there are good studies. We did work with uh dogs in Tanzania trying to understand how SIV is jumping from domestic animals to chimpanzees. So we had to individually track all the dogs and see that they had common areas in the, you know, crop area next to the park where the chimpanzees are going and the dogs are meeting. So maybe it's not that much individual animals, but it's patterns that lead you to areas where these encounters occur and that's what really you should care about, you know, more than the individual tracks.

annotations.provide supporting evidence: The speaker mentions using stable isotopes to mark organisms, providing a specific example of a method for tracking movement, which supports the discussion on how to measure movement relevant to disease transmission.

annotations.express agreement: The speaker says "I agree that, you know, it's complicated", agreeing with the previous discussion about the challenges of translating individual studies to general patterns of mobility.

annotations.present new idea: The speaker introduces the idea that patterns of animal encounters, rather than individual tracks, are what researchers should focus on to understand disease transmission.

utterance: Mike Wimberly: If I could just uh quickly interject, I've I've been listening and you definitely have a some themes emerging here. I I think in terms of the scale issue, you know, I'm hearing a lot of consensus about the value of, you know, individual animal level studies. Um, you know, potentially there's value even in, you know, doing more of those tracking individual animals uh, you know, over time in terms of uh, you know, maybe infection by various pathogens. And you you know, there's a need for, you know, those very detailed uh and precise measurements to often, you know, to be able to disentangle uh the complexities of a local disease transmission cycle. Um, often, you know, the specific characteristics of that will not extrapolate to other areas, but I think there's a big potential for gaining a better understanding of important mechanisms that are, you know, that are often broadly more important beyond an individual system. the other thing I I kind of hear everyone kind of also sort of maybe almost using that as a reference point but stretching toward this idea, you know, toward the the fuzzier picture of you know, what types of data, what framework do we need for a you know, maybe something in the context of much larger scale continental to global surveillance. And you know, I I kind of feel like what you're reaching for there is some level of abstraction. Because when you when you get up there, you're not going to be dealing with individual animals. you know, it's not going to be I think it's we all recognize, it's not going to be feasible to track every single animal on the continent. But you know, what what is it that would be the most useful, you know, would it be, you know, just throwing out one example off the top of my head, is it, you know, much better uh, you know, detailed maps of key migration routes. being able to understand, you know, the timing of migration, how they might light up earlier or later in different years. Um, you know, when particular species might be moving, how those might be shifting from year to year. So, uh anyway, I I just wanted to try to um, you know, try to frame some of those ideas in terms of where I hear you all going. But uh, I'll kind of put it back to the the group now.

annotations.encourage participation: Mike concludes by putting the discussion back to the group, inviting further contributions and participation.

utterance: Bethany McGregor: Yeah, so I typically work on things biting midges, they're also known as noums because these are exceptionally tiny insects. Um but then we might not necessarily know what's happening within that farm or maybe we don't care all that much about find the details what's happening within that farm. But understanding the connectivity between those nodes is something that would be slightly more feasible. Um both from obviously from a farm standpoint that's very feasible because you know what cow is moving from farm A to farm B. But then also in wildlife if you if you have a population that's structured like that more of a kind of standard metapopulation, um you can use, you know, potentially genetic tools where you only need to sample a few individuals to understand something about connectivity between those nodes.
